prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCOSMOS02
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Measure kinematics in ALMA continuum counterparts to this Herschel DSFG.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We set up the correlator to observe CO(J=3-2) as our top priority spectral line in baseband 1. We placed a second baseband to cover the HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) lines. Each of these uses FDM mode to obtain the broadest spectral coverage offered by the ALMA correlator in FDM mode, since the spectral resolution of TDM mode is insufficient for kinematic measurements of narrow spectral lines. This yields a native spectral resolution of 3 km/s. We will spectral average to 12 km/s to reduce the data rate by a factor of 4. Our targets are expected to have FWHM line widths of ~500 km/s, so 12 km/s is more than sufficient for our purposes. The third and fourth basebands are placed in the upper sideband to maximize sensitivity to continuum emission. These use TDM mode to minimize the data rate.

The 5 components identified in the ALMA 870um map of HCOSMOS02 have FWHM source sizes of 0.15 - 0.45 arcsec. We desire 0.2 arcsec resolution because it offers the best compromise: for the smallest counterpart, we get a firm size measurement; for the largest counterpart, we avoid over-resolving the target.
The largest angular size of the targets is well established from our existing ALMA, CARMA, and PdBI observations to be < 1 arcsec for each component.

We use our existing CO(3-2) detections of HCOSMOS02 to guide our sensitivity calculations. The spectra of the three components detected by CARMA are comparable to each other, within the uncertainty of the measurements. They each show peak line flux densities of 4 mJy, FWHM line widths of 500 km/s, and line fluxes of 2 Jy km/s. Our goal is to spatially resolve each component into 3 independent synthesized beams. If the emission is spread evenly between each beam, then the expected flux of each component is 0.67 Jy km/s. Reaching a 10-sigma detection requires a flux rms of 0.067 Jy km/s. Adopting 50 km/s velocity bins and assuming the emission is spread over 800 km/s, we require a per-channel rms of 0.35 mJy to reach the desired flux rms level. S/N > 10 in multiple spatial resolution elements is essential for reliable modeling of the kinematics.
We do not expect to detect the continuum emission from this target.
We have attempted to minimize the data rate as much as possible.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HXMM20
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Search for CO from ALMA continuum counterparts to this Herschel DSFG.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are conducting a search for CO from targets which are expected to lie at z=1.5 - 3.5 based on their Herschel/SPIRE colors. The 3mm atmospheric window is therefore the ideal place to conduct our search. 5 tunings are required to cover this window fully. We use the default parameters in "spectral scan" mode, covering a frequency range of 84. GHz to 113.2 GHz. This includes the TDM correlator mode and yields spectral resolution of 31 MHz.

Our goal is to detect, not resolve each ALMA continuum counterpart. The 5 components identified in the ALMA 870um map of HXMM20 have FWHM source sizes of 0.15 - 0.45 arcsec, and are separated from each other by >1 arcsec. We desire 1 arcsec resolution since it is the coarsest resolution that still ensures none of the ALMA continuum counterparts will be blended together.
The largest angular size of the targets is well established from our existing ALMA, CARMA, and PdBI observations to be < 1 arcsec for each component.

We use our existing CO(3-2) detections of HCOSMOS02 to guide our sensitivity calculations. The spectra of the three components detected by CARMA are comparable to each other, within the uncertainty of the measurements. They each show peak line flux densities of 4 mJy, FWHM line widths of 500 km/s, and line fluxes of 2 Jy km/s. Our goal is to detect, not resolve each component. Therefore, the expected flux is 2 Jy km/s. Reaching a 10-sigma detection requires a flux rms of 0.2 Jy km/s. Adopting 50 km/s velocity bins and assuming the emission is spread over 800 km/s, we require a per-channel rms of 1 mJy to reach the desired flux rms level. S/N > 10 is critical to ensure a robust measurement of the spectroscopic redshift. It also leaves open the possibility of detecting additional ALMA continuum counterparts that are fainter than sources detected by CARMA.
We do not expect to detect the continuum emission from this target.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HELAISS02
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Search for CO from ALMA counterparts to this Herschel DSFG.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are conducting a search for CO from targets which are expected to lie at z=1.5 - 3.5 based on their Herschel/SPIRE colors. The 3mm atmospheric window is therefore the ideal place to conduct our search. 5 tunings are required to cover this window fully. We use the default parameters in "spectral scan" mode, covering a frequency range of 84. GHz to 113.2 GHz. This includes the TDM correlator mode and yields spectral resolution of 31 MHz.

Our goal is to detect, not resolve each ALMA continuum counterpart. The 5 components identified in the ALMA 870um map of HELAISS02 have FWHM source sizes of 0.15 - 0.45 arcsec, and are separated from each other by >1 arcsec. We desire 1 arcsec resolution since it is the coarsest resolution that still ensures none of the ALMA continuum counterparts will be blended together.
The largest angular size of the targets is well established from our existing ALMA, CARMA, and PdBI observations to be < 1 arcsec for each component.

We use our existing CO(3-2) detections of HCOSMOS02 to guide our sensitivity calculations. The spectra of the three components detected by CARMA are comparable to each other, within the uncertainty of the measurements. They each show peak line flux densities of 4 mJy, FWHM line widths of 500 km/s, and line fluxes of 2 Jy km/s. Our goal is to detect, not resolve each component. Therefore, the expected flux is 2 Jy km/s. Reaching a 10-sigma detection requires a flux rms of 0.2 Jy km/s. Adopting 50 km/s velocity bins and assuming the emission is spread over 800 km/s, we require a per-channel rms of 1 mJy to reach the desired flux rms level. S/N > 10 is critical to ensure a robust measurement of the spectroscopic redshift. It also leaves open the possibility of detecting additional ALMA continuum counterparts that are fainter than sources detected by CARMA.
We do not expect to detect the continuum emission from this target.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: AzTECC9
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Measure kinematics in ALMA continuum counterparts to this AzTEC DSFG.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We set up the correlator to observe CO(J=3-2) as our top priority spectral line in baseband 1. We placed a second baseband to cover the HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) lines. Each of these uses FDM mode to obtain the broadest spectral coverage offered by the ALMA correlator in FDM mode, since the spectral resolution of TDM mode is insufficient for kinematic measurements of narrow spectral lines. This yields a native spectral resolution of 3 km/s. We will spectral average to 12 km/s to reduce the data rate by a factor of 4. Our targets are expected to have FWHM line widths of ~500 km/s, so 12 km/s is more than sufficient for our purposes. The third and fourth basebands are placed in the upper sideband to maximize sensitivity to continuum emission. These use TDM mode to minimize the data rate.

The 3 components identified in the ALMA 1.3mm map of AzTECC9 have FWHM source sizes of 0.15 - 0.45 arcsec. We desire 0.2 arcsec resolution because it offers the best compromise: for the smallest counterpart, we get a firm size measurement; for the largest counterpart, we avoid over-resolving the target.
The largest angular size of the targets is well established from our existing ALMA, CARMA, and PdBI observations to be < 1 arcsec for each component.

The ALMA 1.3mm flux densities of the three components of AzTECC9 are comparable to the 870um flux densities of HCOSMOS02. This suggests that HCOSMOS02 can serve as a conservative upper limit on the time required to achieve our science goals. We therefore use our existing CO(3-2) detections of HCOSMOS02 to guide our sensitivity calculations.
The spectra of the three components of HCOSMOS02 detected by CARMA are comparable to each other, within the uncertainty of the measurements. They each show peak line flux densities of 4 mJy, FWHM line widths of 500 km/s, and line fluxes of 2 Jy km/s. Our goal is to spatially resolve each component into 3 independent synthesized beams. If the emission is spread evenly between each beam, then the expected flux of each component is 0.67 Jy km/s. Reaching a 10-sigma detection requires a flux rms of 0.067 Jy km/s. Adopting 50 km/s velocity bins and assuming the emission is spread over 800 km/s, we require a per-channel rms of 0.35 mJy to reach the desired flux rms level. S/N > 10 in multiple spatial resolution elements is essential for reliable modeling of the kinematics.
We do not expect to detect the continuum emission from this target.
We have attempted to minimize the data rate as much as possible.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our team has used ALMA continuum imaging from Cycle 0 and Cycle 2 to discover that wide-field Herschel and ASTE/AzTEC surveys can be used to uncover blends of multiple DSFGs with pairwise separations that are significantly smaller than what is found from ALMA follow-up of other single-dish surveys. Theoretical simulations have difficulty reproducing this population of multi-component and small-separation DSFGs, but they suggest that a portion of the population may be due to line-of-sight projection effects and are not physically related. We obtained CARMA and PdBI obsevations of CO(3-2) and CO(4-3) indicating this is not the case for one target, but a larger sample size is needed to push this test to the next level. We propose a redshift search for CO emission in 2 targets with four or more ALMA counterparts from our Cycle 0 program and CO imaging of 2 additional targets with 3 or more ALMA counterparts and a known redshift. The redshift search data are critically needed to test whether the ALMA counterparts are physically associated, and the CO kinematics are essential to inform theories of how stars form in these complex systems.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00539.S PI: D. Riechers Title: Lensing Properties of the Brightest Herschel-Selected Submillimeter Galaxies 2013.1.00118.S PI: M. Aravena Title: Unveiling the population of high-redshift submillimeter galaxies with ALMA 1.2 mm imaging
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
